name: Admin UI
overview: Admin UI is a internal tool used by cross-functioning teams for managing users and various data configurations. The front-end was developed using Angular and Nebular UI (CSS) framework. The backend is built on Spring Boot and Cassandra DB for CRUD operations and interaction with other microservices. User are authenticated using internal SSO and the application is currently being used in production.

name: Gaming Dashboard
overview: A internal, data visualization platform for viewing cloud gaming user and network engagement stats during the initial launch. This interactive data application was developed using Python and Plotly's Dash framework. Stats are loaded from local JSON files which are periodically checked for updates using multi-threading. The backend pipeline consists of Bash/PySpark scripts that pull and aggregates data daily from Hadoop Hive tables to the JSON files.

name: App Classify
overview: An internal tool for consuming and managing signatures for identifying mobile applications based on customers' usage. This was developed using Flask and jQuery/AJAX for add/delete operations on signatures stored in local SQLite DB. The interface was built with Bootstrap based DataTable library. Common count of signatures are automatically calculated whenever an entry is added or deleted. This internal tool was developed as means to keep track of the signatures that were identified through scripts.

name: Network Digest
overview: A dashboard design prototype developed with Adobe XD for visualizing user and network engagment stats/insights in various categories. This is a POC of an internal application or platform, used by executives, for quickly digesting up-to-date stats and insights. Network Digest was created during my internship in 2019.

name: LOL-TANA
overview: Think of the Cortana from the Halo Series. LOL-Tana is an in-game, AI for a League of Legends (LoL) game that displays the win percentage calculated based on important in-game factors. The user chooses which Champion is being played and throughout the game, enters different metrics like number of kills, Creep Score, and which objectives were secured to determine the chances of winning that game. This determination is based on a Logistic Regression model, developed and trained using 1000 past matches of a professional LoL player (C9 Sneaky).
